unnormalised: ## The Great Indian Return Ruckus: Avoiding a 'Kalesh' at Checkout
normalised: ## The Great Indian Return Ruckus: Avoiding a 'Kalesh' at Checkout

unnormalised: Let's be honest, returning something you bought online or in a brick-and-mortar shop is a bit like navigating Mumbai traffic during rush hour. You're inching forward, praying you don't get sideswiped by unexpected policy changes, and hoping you actually reach your destination (a full refund, preferably) in one piece.
normalised: Let's be honest, returning something you bought online or in a brick-and-mortar shop is a bit like navigating Mumbai traffic during rush hour. You're inching forward, praying you don't get sideswiped by unexpected policy changes, and hoping you actually reach your destination (a full refund, preferably) in one piece.

unnormalised: We've all been there. You order that snazzy new kurta online, imagining yourself looking like Shah Rukh Khan in Dilwale, only to discover it fits more like… well, your uncle's outdated pajamas. Or you excitedly buy a new pressure cooker from a local shop in Karol Bagh, only to realize it's designed for a nuclear family of 20, not your humble 2BHK flat of 600 sq ft.

unnormalised: And then comes the Return Policy gauntlet. Is it 7 days? 15 days? Only for items in "mint condition," untouched by human hands (good luck proving THAT after you've tried squeezing yourself into that kurta!). Did you keep the original packaging? Because if not, may God have mercy on your soul.

unnormalised: Don't even get me started on return shipping. Paying Rs. 200 to ship back something that cost Rs. 500 feels like a personal affront from the Universe. It's like Dr. Sharma charging you Rs. 1000 for a consultation and then asking you to pay extra for the prescription paper!
normalised: Don't even get me started on return shipping. Paying rupee two hundred to ship back something that cost rupee five hundred feels like a personal affront from the Universe. It's like Doctor Sharma charging you rupee one thousand for a consultation and then asking you to pay extra for the prescription paper!

unnormalised: So, what’s the solution? Read the return policy. I know, thrilling stuff. But seriously, knowing the rules beforehand prevents a lot of potential 'kalesh' (drama). Check for things like restocking fees, return windows, and whether they offer store credit or a full refund. And for the love of Durga Maa, keep that original packaging!

unnormalised: Next time you're buying that ridiculously overpriced phone cover online, take a minute to understand the return policy. It might just save you from a 'return rumble' worthy of a Bollywood blockbuster. Remember, a little bit of foresight can prevent a whole lot of frustration. Now go forth and shop… cautiously!
